Title: Ac Joint Reconstruction
ContentBlocksJSON: [{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Shoulder AC Joint Surgery"},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Diagnosis"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"The AC joint dislocation is easy to diagnose and identify. On clinical examination, the shoulder top appears prominent in comparison to the other side."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"X-ray: X-ray of both the shoulders (AP view), with weights held in the hands pulling the arm down helps in identifying this condition. The grade of injury needs to be determined as Grade 1 and 2 can be managed with conservative management. Higher grades of injury Grade 3 to 6 are usually treated with surgery."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"MRI Scan: MRI Scan helps in understanding the extent of injury to the ligaments holding the AC (Acromio-Clavicular) joint as well as the CC (Coraco-Clavicular) ligaments. This helps in determining the grade of injury. MRI Scan also helps in ruling out any other additional injuries to the shoulder joint"},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Treatment"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"AC Joint injuries Grade 1 and 2 will not affect the functioning of the arm. Hence a broad arm sling for 2 to 3 weeks till the pain and swelling settles down would be sufficient. One needs to be aware that the point of the shoulder may appear more prominent compared to the other side permanently. However, as function of the arm is not hampered."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"AC (Acromio-Clavicular) Reconstruction"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Surgery is recommended in people with Grade 3 to 6 AC joint injury. AC joint reconstruction surgery is a day care surgery. It is done either as a key hole (arthroscopy) or mini-open surgery. A tight rope with fiber-tape and small titanium buttons is used. A small hole is drilled through the clavicle (collar bone) and then through the coracoid (part of the scapula – shoulder bone). The button is passed through the bones and then flipped. It is then tightened to compress the AC joint back to place. The reduction of the joint back to place is confirmed by an x-ray imaging during surgery."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"AC Joint Rehabilitation"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Post-surgery a broad arm sling is needed for 2 to 3 weeks. Early mobilization of the arm is recommended. From the day 1, one needs to start moving the fingers, wrist and elbow. Once the surgery site pain improves, it is recommended to start moving the shoulder. Upto 6 weeks, overhead activities are to be avoided. Rehabilitation with physiotherapy is important to get the shoulder muscle strength back and the smooth movement of the muscles. Return to active sports is expected around 4 months post surgery."}]

Title: Achilles Tendon Tear
ContentBlocksJSON: [{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Overview"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"The Achilles tendon is the largest tendon in the body which attaches to the back of the heel. It is part of the calf muscles and primarily helps in push off during running. Achilles tendon integrity is necessary for running, climbing stairs and a lot of other daily activities."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"How does the tendon tear?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"The area of Achilles tendon insertion to the heel bone is subject to a lot of stress as we sprint suddenly. Without proper warm up sudden sprinting is one of the common reasons for the tendon tear. The tendon tear is typically seen in middle aged sprinters. The tear is typically seen in the distal 1/3rd of the tendon 5 to 6 cm away from the insertion. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Who gets Achilles Tendon Tear?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"This is often seen in the age group between 30 and 50. It can occurs in both sporting and non-sporting population. In sporting population the reason for Achilles tendinopathy are"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Poor warm up"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Restarting playing / running after a long gap"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Sudden escalation in the intensity of the workouts"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Over use (Not having gap days or rotation to help heal the stress injuries)."},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Occasionally it can be due to direct injury to the achilles tendon."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Symptoms"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Sudden pain while sprinting. It feels as if you have been suddenly hit by a heavy stick in the calf area."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Sudden loss of power."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"difficulty walking."},{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Natural History (Progression of disease in the absence of treatment)"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"The Achilles tendon tear leads to loss of power to propel the body weight over the forefoot. The tear does not heal naturally. Although pain resolves over a period of few months, clumsiness with walking over the steep surfaces and climbing the stairs up and down perseveres for long term.  "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"When to seek medical help?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"If the pain is not getting relieved with heat therapy, analgesic gels and sprays and with basic warm up stretches, then it is necessary to see a Sports Orthopedics Surgeon. The diagnosis is based on the symptoms and clinical examination. X-ray may sometimes be asked for, however the x-ray helps to rule out the heel bone (Haglund deformity) abnormality causing the Achilles tendon irritiation."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"What happens to Achilles tendinopathy if no treatment is undertaken?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"The micro-injuries of the Achilles tendon may persist and are likely to keep stopping you from doing further activities such as running. Natural healing of the tendon can take place over a period of 12 to 24 months, but in majority the pain persists unless the right kind of remedies is undertaken."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"What happens when I visit the Consultant?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"You will be asked about your sporting history, symptoms further to that so far. Consultant will examine you and discuss the treatment modalities."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"What are the treatment modalities?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"The treatment modalities vary from conservative management such as walker boot with wedges to Achilles tendon repair."}]

Title: ACL Injury
ContentBlocksJSON: [{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Overview"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"ACL or Anterior Cruciate Ligament is one of the 4 main ligaments in the knee joint. Ligaments are rubbery ropes that connect and hold the 2 bones together. ACL along with its fellow ligament PCL in the center of the knee joint protects and stabilizes the knee against translational forces (front to back) and also against rotational forces (twisting)."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Why & how does it happen?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"ACL tear are one of commonest injury to the knee joint. It typically happens when the knee is twisted suddenly while the foot is still planted on the ground. When the twisting forces overwhelm what the ACL can manage to resist, the ACL tear occurs. Majority of the ACL injuries occur due to non-contact in the sense without a direct injury to the knee."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Who gets this injury?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"We see this typically in sporting population such as footballers, basketball players, cricketers, badminton and so on. Fall from the two wheelers, bikes and cycles are another common reason for this injury. Typical age group is 20 to 45 years."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Symptoms"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Sudden severe pain"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"In some loud POP sound"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Inability to walk"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Feeling that knee will give away and not supporting well"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Swelling appears usually few hours after injury"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Within a week most patients with ACL tear will be able to walk with a slight limp"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Persistence of instability sensation and pain in certain movements and activities"},{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Natural History (Progression of disease in the absence of treatment)"},{"type":"paragraph","text":" The ACL tear will gradually become pain-free over a period of few weeks. However, as ACL cannot heal naturally, the instability and pain on sudden change of direction of twisting movements of the leg persists indefinitely. That can over a period of time lead to further soft tissue injuries (meniscus and cartilage) in the joint and arthritis at the earlier age than anticipated. "},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Sudden pain while sprinting. It feels as if you have been suddenly hit by a heavy stick in the calf area."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Sudden loss of power."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"difficulty walking."},{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Natural History (Progression of disease in the absence of treatment)"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"The Achilles tendon tear leads to loss of power to propel the body weight over the forefoot. The tear does not heal naturally. Although pain resolves over a period of few months, clumsiness with walking over the steep surfaces and climbing the stairs up and down perseveres for long term.  "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"When to seek medical help?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​Initial assessment, an x-ray and pain relieving medicines is what is needed as an immediate remedy. Further assessment by an expert Arthroscopy Surgeon and MRI scan are necessary to analyze the extent of injury."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"What happens to ACL if no treatment is undertaken?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​ACL does not heal by itself as it has poor blood supply and the joint fluid in the knee does not allow it to heal. In spite of ACL injury, one can walk, cycle, swim, do certain gym activities and even run on a treadmill once the pain has improved after few weeks. However, activities such as running criss-cross, going up and down the stairs, on the ground/court games or even something as simple as running behind a bus in a tangent way can lead to pain or feeling that something is going to give away."},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Secondly as the knee will keep on skidding, it increases wear and tear in the joint leading to osteoarthritis at an earlier age than expected."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"What happens when I visit the Consultant?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​You will be asked about the nature of injury, symptoms further to that so far. Consultant will examine you and discuss the treatment modalities."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"What are the treatment options?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​A partial ACL tear may still be treatable with PRP Injections, however, a complete treatment often needs an ACL repair / reconstruction surgery."}]

Title: ACL Retear
ContentBlocksJSON: [{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Overview"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"ACL or Anterior Cruciate Ligament retear is fortunately rare. However, we come across the retears on regular basis as a tertiary centre for ligament reconstructions. Retear can be either due to a new episode of an acute injury or alternatovely due to repetitive strain over a period of time. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Why & how does it happen?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"ACL retear can occur due to a further injury with significant enough twisting of the knee with foot planted. This may happen and would be overwhelming injury for the native ACL as well anyway. Alternatively, it can be due to poor surgical technique and tunnel placements which puts the grafts at risk. Third reason being incomplete rehabilitation and poor refining of the landing technique. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Who gets this injury?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"We see this typically in sporting population such as footballers, basketball players, cricketers, badminton etc particularly on early return to sports with inadequate rehabilitation."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Symptoms"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Instability"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Swelling"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Limited range of movement initially"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Occasional locking (bucket handle tears)"},{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Natural History (Progression of disease in the absence of treatment)"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"The ACL retear will gradually become pain-free over a period of few weeks. However, as ACL cannot heal naturally, the instability and pain on sudden change of direction of twisting movements of the leg persists indefinitely. That can over a period of time lead to further soft tissue injuries (meniscus and cartilage) in the joint and arthritis at the earlier age than anticipated. "},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Sudden pain while sprinting. It feels as if you have been suddenly hit by a heavy stick in the calf area."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Sudden loss of power."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"difficulty walking."},{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Natural History (Progression of disease in the absence of treatment)"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"The ACL retear will gradually become pain-free over a period of few weeks. However, as ACL cannot heal naturally, the instability and pain on sudden change of direction of twisting movements of the leg persists indefinitely. That can over a period of time lead to further soft tissue injuries (meniscus and cartilage) in the joint and arthritis at the earlier age than anticipated. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"When to seek medical help?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"A thorough assessment by an expert Arthroscopy Surgeon and MRI scan (preferably 3 Tesla imaging) are necessary to analyze the extent of injury."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"What happens to ACL if no treatment is undertaken?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"ACL retear along with other joint problems such as cartilage loss and meniscal tears can hasten the onset of arthritis of the joint. Stable joint with functioning ACL is desirable to minimise risk of further wear and tear and injuries. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"What happens when I visit the Consultant?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"You will be asked about the nature of injury, symptoms further to that so far. Carrying the previous health records, discharge summary would be helpful, as the Consultant needs to assess all of these information. Consultant will examine you and discuss the treatment modalities. Pros and cons of Revision ACL reconstruction surgery will be discussed. "}]

Title: Ankle Pain
ContentBlocksJSON: [{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Overview"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Ankle is a complex joint where 3 bones come together to form the joint. Twisting of ankle leading to ligament (rubbery structure connecting the two bones) injury is one of the common reasons for the ankle pain. Ankle pain and stiffness can affect the knee as well due to increased stress transmission to the knee."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Symptoms"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Pain"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Swelling"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Stiffness"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Instability"},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Conditions"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"ATFL Ligament Injury"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Lateral Ligament Injury"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Deltoid Ligament Injury"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Achilles Tendon Tear"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Achilles Tendinopathy"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Cartilage loss"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Osteochondritis Dissecans"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Fractures around the ankle joint"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Osteoarthritis of ankle"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Plantar Fasciitis"},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"When to see the Doctor?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​Ankle acute injury with swelling, pain and inability to bear weight needs the attention of the Doctor. Recurrent ankle twisting or persistent pain needs to be addressed by the Doctor."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Prevention of ankle pain and injuries"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Appropriate footwear for activities"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Appropriate care of the ankle injuries"}]

Title: Annotations
ContentBlocksJSON: [{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Bone"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Bone is a living structure made up of calcium (hydroxyapatite) and proteins. Bones give the shape and structure to the body and protects other organs. Bones do have blood supply and keep remodelling themselves constantly. Bones are one of the few structures which have got the potential to self heal in the appropriate condition. "},{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Cartilage"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Cartilage is the smooth lining of the joint. It is present in most joints. It prevents the sharp edges of the bone from rubbing against each other. Cartilage does not have blood supply and hence is poor at self healing. "},{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Joint"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Joint is the place where 2 bones meet. Joints are designed to allow movement in certain directions. Joints naturally like movement and keeping them still for long leads to stiffness. "},{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Ligament"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Ligaments are the rubbery ropes holding the two bones together at the joint. The ligaments allow movement in a certain direction and become stiff in the opposite direction. Ligaments outside the joint have potential to self heal to an extent, but not the ligaments in the middle of the joints. "},{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Muscle"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Muscle is a sofisticated structure which contracts and stretches to help place a particular joint in a particular position. Muscles have good blood supply and have a good potential to self heal. Muscles naturally like to move and stretch. Keeping them still in a certain position for long periods makes them become stiff and also become weak (atrophy). "},{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Nerve"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Nerves are cord like structures which pass all the way fron brain to spinal cord to the tips of our hands and feet. They are the wires which carry the signals for our muscles to move. They also carry the signal back to the brain regarding the position and condition of our joints and other structures. "},{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Tendon"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Tendon is the tail part of the muscle which connects it to the bone. Tendon is a rubbery stiff structure which has got very minimal stretching capacity. The structure and components of the tendon and ligament are similar in many regards. "},{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Vessels"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Blood vessels are of two types, namely the arteries and veins. The arteries carry blood from the heart to the hands and feet. Veins bring the blood back from the extremities to the heart. If arteries are not functioning well, one may experience pain on walking or worse death (necrosis) of the toes and further structures upwards. If veins are not functioning well, then one would experience swelling and ache in the legs or arms. "}]

Title: ATFL Ligament Injury – Ankle
ContentBlocksJSON: [{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Overview"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"ATFL or Anterior Talo Fibular Ligament is one of the 3 main ligaments on the outer side of the ankle joint. It is a rubbery rope that holds the 2 bones together. ATFL along with its fellow ligaments CFL and PTFL stabilses the ankle on the outer side.  ATFL being in the front part of the ankle on the outer side, protects the joint against inward twisting forces particularly when the ankle is bent downwards. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Why & how does it happen?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"ATFL tear are one of commonest injuries to the ankle joint. It typically happens when the ankle and foot gets twisted inwards and the body load falls on the twisted ankle. When the twisting forces overwhelm what the ATFL can manage, the CFL tear occurs. It often occurs due to missing a step on the stairs, or on the playground. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Who gets this injury?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Women are more prone to this injury. It is common not only in sporting population but also in general public. Fall from the two wheelers, bikes and cycles are another common reason for this injury. Typical age group is 20 to 50 years."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Symptoms"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Sudden severe ankle pain"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"In some loud POP sound"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Painful to walk"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Feeling that the ankle will give away and not supporting"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Swelling appears usually few hours later"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Within a week most patients with ATFL tear will be able to walk with a slight limp"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Persistence of instability sensation and pain in certain movements and activities"},{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Natural History (Progression of disease in the absence of treatment)"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"ATFL has got the potential to self heal, however proper treatment is necessary. For the ligament to heal, an average of 4 to 6 weeks is required. Upto 6 months your body will keep trying to heal this ligament. After that if the laxity persists, that may remain so for rest of the life unless an intervention takes place. If the ATFL does not heal or if it heals with a stretch, then it is likely to buckle repeatedly and cause further ankle injuries. In addition, sitting cross legged continues to cause pain if ATFL has not healed well. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"When to seek medical help?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Initial assessment, an x-ray and pain relieving medicines is what is needed as an immediate remedy. Further assessment by an expert Orthopedic Surgeon is useful. Most ATFL injuries do not need an MRI scan during the initial phase of treatment. ​"},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"What happens when I visit the Consultant?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"You will be asked about the nature of injury, symptoms further to that so far. Consultant will examine you and discuss the treatment modalities. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"What are the treatment Modalities?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"The treatment modalities vary from simple ankle binder to PRP Injection to Ankle Ligament Surgery depending upon the grade of tear and the chronicity."}]

Title: AVN Hip (Avascular Necrosis) (Osteonecrosis)
ContentBlocksJSON: [{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Overview"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Avascular necrosis is basically death of the bone. One of the common areas it affects is the hip joint. The upper portion of the thigh bone is in the shape of a ball and forms a joint with the socket of the pelvic bone. These to bone ends together is called hip joint. The ball or head of the thigh bone (femur) has got the blood supply in a reverse fashion from the neck upwards. The blood vessels around the neck of the femur form a ring from which blood vessels travel upwards to the head of the femur. When the pressure increases in the capsule of the joint, it obstructs the blood supply. This leads to the death of the bone in the head area which is called necrosis. Necrosed bone will not be able to support the cartilage (the lining of the joint) and hence starts collapsing. As the bone collapses the shape of the ball starts changing. This leads to incongruence of the joint leading to arthritis. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Causes"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Joint injury"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Fat deposition"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Cholesterol"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Smoking"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Alcohol"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Obesity"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Sickle cell disease"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Usage of steroids and certain other medications"},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Symptoms​"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Early stages of AVN are often without any symptoms. As the condition worsens one may end up having pain on walking and also notice the stiffness. Pain can gradually worsen and eventually lead to pain at night as well. Pain is commonly felt in the groin area or in the C shaped area around the hip. In some the pain can radiate to the knee."},{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Natural History (Progression of disease in the absence of treatment)"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"AVN of hip is a slow progressing condition, where it gradually progresses from stage 1 to stage 4. This transition takes place over a period of 1 to 3 years. In a small percentage of patients it halts at a particular stage and doesn’t progress. Once it reaches stage 3 and 4, the only option of treatment to cure would be total hip replacement."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"When to see the Doctor?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​This is one condition where the sooner the diagnosis is made the better. In majority of patients, the condition gradually deteriorates. Advanced AVN leads to collapse of the bone and change in the shape of the bone. Once these irreversible changes occur the conservative management may not be ideal for those patients. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"What treatment modalities are available?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​The treatment modalities include medicines, core decompression and stem cell therapy or Total Hip Replacement depending on the stage of avascular necrosis. "}]

Title: Cartilage Tear or Injury
ContentBlocksJSON: [{"type":"paragraph","text":"Cartilage is the smooth lining of the joint which protects the ends of the bones from rubbing against each other and causing pain. The smooth surface of the cartilage with the lubrication in the joint has lower friction coefficient in comparison with any man made joint couples. When the cartilage loss is wide spread all over the joint it is called arthritis. However, specific localized areas of cartilage loss can still cause pain and friction."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Causes"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​Localized areas of cartilage loss can happen due to various conditions"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Chondromalacia patella (Loss of cartilage behind the knee cap)"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Osteochondritis dissecans (cartilage and underlying bone loss in a specific area of the joint)"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Trauma"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Iatrogenic (previous surgeries)"},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Where does cartilage loss affect?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​The most common joint where we see these injuries is the knee. Ankle cartilage loss in the talar dome (the upper dome portion of the ankle bone) is another common area of problem. This is usually secondary to injury. In the knee we commonly see this behind the knee cap, in the adjacent area of the thigh bone, lower end of the thigh bone and also in the upper portion of the leg bone."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"​Classification"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"International Cartilage Repair Society (ICRS) Grading system"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Grade 1. Nearly normal (superficial lesions)"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Grade 2. Abnormal (lesions with < 50% of cartilage depth)"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Grade 3. Severely abnormal (loss of >50% of cartilage depth)"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Grade 4 Severely abnormal (Exposure of the subchondral bone)"},{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Natural History (Progression of disease in the absence of treatment)"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Cartilage has poor blood supply and has got very limited capacity to regenerate and repair itself. Without treatment, at best it can remain the same, and at worse the cartilage loss can gradually increase in depth and also become widespread in the whole joint. If the cartilage injury spreads to the whole joint, then the term “Arthritis” gets used to describe that."},{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Management"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​Early grades (Grade 1 and 2) of cartilage can often be managed either with physiotherapy, activity modification, collagen supplements or PRP (Platelet Rich plasma) injection."},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Advanced grades (Grade 3 and 4) of cartilage damage needs chondroplasty (cartilage regeneration technology)."}]

Title: Chondromalacia Patella
ContentBlocksJSON: [{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Overview"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"The loss of the smooth cartilage lining the undersurface of the patella is described as chondromalacia patella. It may involve one side of the patella (medial or lateral facet) or both sides. Occasionally kissing lesions of cartilage loss are seen on patellar side and also on the femur (thigh bone) trochlear area. The depth and extent of the cartilage tear or loss matters in terms of symptoms and also the response to specific treatment modalities. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Causes"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Localized areas of cartilage loss can happen due to various conditions"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Chondromalacia patella (Loss of cartilage behind the knee cap)"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Osteochondritis dissecans (cartilage and underlying bone loss in a specific area of the joint)"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Trauma"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Iatrogenic (previous surgeries)"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Generalised loss of cartilage occurs with wear and tear over the longer period of time."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Osteoarthritis"},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"How does chondromalacia affect?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​The common symptoms of patellar chondromalacia are pain in the front of the knee particularly with activities such as climbing the stairs and squats. Pain is often less on playing when you have warmed up. Along side with pain, clicks, instability are often experiences. Occasionally swelling is noted. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Classification"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"International Cartilage Repair Society (ICRS) Grading system"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Grade 1. Nearly normal (superficial lesions)"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Grade 2. Abnormal (lesions with < 50% of cartilage depth)"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Grade 3. Severely abnormal (loss of >50% of cartilage depth)"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Grade 4 Severely abnormal (Exposure of the subchondral bone)"},{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Natural History (Progression of disease in the absence of treatment)"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Cartilage has poor blood supply and has got very limited capacity to regenerate and repair itself. Without treatment, at best it can remain the same, and at worse the cartilage loss can gradually increase in depth and also become widespread in the whole joint. If the cartilage injury spreads to the whole joint, then the term “Arthritis” gets used to describe that."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Management"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Early grades (Grade 1 and 2) of cartilage can often be managed either with physiotherapy, activity modification, collagen supplements or PRP (Platelet Rich plasma) injection. Advanced grades (Grade 3 and 4) of cartilage damage needs chondroplasty (cartilage regeneration technology)."}]

Title: De Quervains Tenosynovitis
ContentBlocksJSON: [{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Overview"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"APL (Abductor Hallucis Longus) and EHB (Extensor Pollicis Brevis) are the two long muscle tendons from forearm that control the movement of the thumb. These tendons help pull the thumb up and also to stretch it sideways. These tendons are held in place by the band which is just proximal ( above) to the wrist at the base of the thumb. If the band is tighter than necessary, it restricts the movements of the thumb and causes pain. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Why does De Quervains Tenosynovitis happen?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"As the tendon has to pass under the band of tissue around the wrist area, the tendons can get thickened and also the band above can become more stiff. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Who gets De Quervains Tenosynovitis?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"De Quervains Tenosynovitis is more common in diabetics, patients with hypothyroidism, musicians, keyboard users. Pregnant women during pregnancy or post delivery are likely to get  De Quervains tenosynovitis due to the hormonal changes and weight changes. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Symptoms"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Pain on lifting the objects"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Thumb base pain"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Wrist pain"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Pain with stiffness in movement of thumb and wrist"},{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Natural History (Progression of disease in the absence of treatment)"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"De Quervain’s tenosynovitis is a non-progressive condition. However the debilitating symptoms of pain and stiffness in using the thumb may remain for 1 to 2 years. The pain gradually resolves over a long period of time, but some amount of stiffness is likely to persist. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"When to seek medical help?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Clinical assessment is sufficient to diagnose this condition. X-ray are un-necessary. Pain relieving medicines will have temporary relief. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"​What happens when I visit the Consultant?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"You will be asked about the nature of injury, symptoms further to that so far. Consultant will examine you and discuss the treatment modalities. In majority of cases, MRI scan wouldn’t be required in the initial assessment. The consultant may ask you to go undergo blood tests to check for the blood sugar levels and thyroid hormone levels.  "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"What are the Treatment Options?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"The De Quervains tenosynovitis treatment modalities range from under warm water exercises to an injection to De Quervains release surgery depending upon the nature of symptoms and duration."}]

Title: Fat Pad Impingement Knee
ContentBlocksJSON: [{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Overview"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Fat pads are the wad of fat blobs which sit behind and on either side the patellar tendon in the front part of the knee. The fat pads are closely associated with the patellar tendon. Although they are not known to have any major function, they contain blood vessels that supply to the patellar tendon. Fat Pad impingement is one of the common causes of the knee pain. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Why & how does fat pad impingement happen?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"In runners and sportsman, the fat pads can get irritated along with patellar tendon. With patellar tendinopathy, the fat pad also gets irritated and inflamed. Once the fat pad gets irritated and swollen, it can get pinched between the femur (thigh bone) and tibia (leg bone). That leads to increased inflammation and further swelling. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Who gets fat pad impingement?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"This is often seen in the age group between 30 and 50. It occurs not only in runners, but also in other sporting population such as footballers, basketball players, cricketers, badminton and so on. The reasons for the fat pad impingement are"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Poor warm up"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Restarting playing / running after a long gap"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Sudden escalation in the intensity of the workouts"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Over use (not having gap days or rotation to help heal the stress injuries)"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Poor patellar tracking"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Patella Baha (low patella)"},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Symptoms"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Pain when running and high intensity leg activities."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Initially pain is not felt while doing workouts, when warmed up."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Anterior knee pain – in and around the patella (knee cap)."},{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Natural History (Progression of disease in the absence of treatment)"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"The inflammation of the fat pad may persist and are likely to keep stopping you from doing activities such as running. Natural resolution of symptoms may occur in some, but in majority the pain recurs on resuming the activities. The recurrent cycles of pain is likely to force one out of any further sporting /exercise based activities. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"When to seek medical help?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"If the pain is not getting relieved with heat therapy, analgesic gels and sprays and with basic warm up stretches, then it is necessary to see a Sports Orthopedics Surgeon. The diagnosis is based on the symptoms and clinical examination. If the symptoms are not improving with simple treatments an MRI scan may be necessary to assess the condition of the fat pads. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"What happens when I visit the Consultant?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"You will be asked about your sporting history, symptoms further to that so far. Consultant will examine you and discuss the treatment modalities."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"What are the treatment Modalities?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"The treatment modalities vary from knee stretches to an injection to the fat pad to reduce the inflammation. In some, arthroscopic (key-hole) surgery and fat pad debridement would be necessary. "}]

Title: Fitness
ContentBlocksJSON: [{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Overview"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"I often get questioned about the best exercise program. This comes particularly from teenagers who are enthusiastic and full of energy. In today’s day and age, it is not difficult to find shed loads of material online pertaining to this topic. However, the arduous task then would be to choose the correct one!"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"I will try to explain the options, safety and reasoning in simple words in a nutshell."},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Before you embark upon one of these routes, you need to sit and think about your goals. If you would like to take up an enduring sports activity such as marathon, then the route would be totally different from if you are trying to bulk up your muscles."},{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Type of Exercises"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"The exercise activities can be broadly classified into 3 groups."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Aerobics (Cardio)"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Weight training"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Stretching exercises"},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Aerobics"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Aerobics is mainly to increase your endurance. Running, Jogging, Cycling Swimming, Treadmill, Cross-trainer are all types of aerobic exercises. One can argue that it is most helpful form of exercise as it helps to improve overall fitness and has got several health benefits including reduction of percentage of body fat. This increases the type-1 muscle fibers, which are important for endurance. However, this does not bulk up the muscles."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Weight Training"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Weight training can help to bulk up the muscles. This can be achieved either by using body weight itself or by using weights in various forms ranging from dumbbells and barbells to specialized equipment in the Gym. One can gain weight through this mode of exercise. Although, this is attractive option for lot of youngsters, most injuries and problems we see in our clinics are the result of poor technique."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Stretching Exercises"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Stretching exercises such as Yoga and Pilates help in keeping joints supple and mobile. It helps in aligning the muscles in the correct direction for action. However, doing stretching exercises immediately prior to weight training may lead to some loss of power."},{"type":"heading","level":2,"text":"Recommendations"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Adequate warm up and cooling down"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Adequate mix of all 3 modes of exercises"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Start slow and build up your training gradually"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"3-4 days a week training"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Adequate Hydration"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Last but not the least, do not make exercise a self inflicted punishment, but an enjoyable activity!"}]

Title: Foot Pain
ContentBlocksJSON: [{"type":"paragraph","text":"Foot comprises of 26 bones. These include tarsal bones, metacarpals and phalanges the toe bones. Foot is a complex structure with arches from front to back as well as inner to outer side. This complex supple structure helps foot to work as a shock absorber and transmits minimal forces upwards to the ankle and further. Foot conditions can be due to injury, stress or a multitude of other conditions including diabetes, vascular problems etc. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Symptoms"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Pain."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Swelling."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Stiffness."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Instability."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Ulcers."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Tingling or Numbness"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Weakness"},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Conditions"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Plantar fasciitis"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Tibialis Posterior Tendon Dysfunction"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Heel Valgus"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Hallux Valgus"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Hallux Rigidus"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Charcot Foot"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Metatarsalgia"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Stress Fractures"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Sinus Tarsi Syndrome"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Fractures"},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"When to see the Doctor?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​Acute foot injury with swelling, pain and inability to bear weight needs the attention of the Doctor. Title: Frozen Shoulder
ContentBlocksJSON: [{"type":"paragraph","text":"Frozen shoulder or adhesive capsulitis is a condition in which shoulder movements are restricted in almost all directions. It is a painful condition. It starts gradually."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Causes"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​Shoulder joint is a ball and a socket joint with a huge range of motion compared to any other joint in the body. It has got a thin capsule along with the ligaments which while holding it in place, will support full range of motion. When the capsule thickens and becomes tighter it causes the stiffness and pain. The exact reason is unknown in majority of these patients. However it is seen more frequently in certain groups of people."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Diabetes Mellitus"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Thyroid disorders"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Parkinsonism"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Post injury"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Post-surgery"},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Symptoms"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Global restriction of range of movements. Loss of external rotation is one of the important signs in the assessment of this condition"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Pain. Day and night time pain"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Stiffness. Restricts the overhead activities"},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"3 Stages of Frozen shoulder"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Freezing stage. All movements of the shoulder are painful and limited. This lasts for 3 to 9 months."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Frozen stage. Pain may slightly improve, however the stiffness gets worse. This lasts for 6 to 12 months."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Thawing stage. Shoulder movements improve to an extent, however it is common to see some residual terminal restriction of range of movement. This lasts for 6 to 24 months."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Natural History (Progression of disease in the absence of treatment)"},{"type":"paragraph","text":" Although the pain component of Frozen shoulder may gradually resolve over the first 12 months, the residual stiffness and restriction of the range of the movements will persist in majority of patients even beyond 2 years in the absence of treatment for the Frozen shoulder."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Prevention"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Good control of diabetes."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Proper management of thyroid disorders."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Early mobilization post injury as feasible."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Early mobilization post-surgery. ​"},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Treatment Options"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Treatment modalities range from physiotherapy – exercise based treatment with or without steroid injection. In people with poor improvement with this, may need manipulation under anaesthesia. In neglected frozen shoulder cases, arthroscopic release of the frozen shoulder would be recommended."}]

Title: Golfers Elbow
ContentBlocksJSON: [{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Overview"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Golfers Elbow or medial epicondylitis affects people in the age group between 30 and 50. It is a repetitive strain injury (RSI). It is due to micro injuries at the starting part of the muscles on the inner side of the elbow (common flexor origin). It feels like a bone pain, but it not a bone problem, but the muscle which starts from this point. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Why & how does Golfers Elbow Injury occur?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Golfers elbow  is due to repetitive strain. It is due to either playing racket sports such as tennis or badminton, but more commonly due to use of keyboards, mobile phones for prolonged periods. Using the vibration tools or wringing clothes can also cause this injury. The micro-injuries to the muscle tendon makes it stiff and painful. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"​Who gets the Golfers Elbow injury?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"It is common in software users, prolonged mobile users, raquet sport players, women doing household chores and people using vibratory tools."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Symptoms"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Pain gradual in onset"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Pain starting from the elbow towards the wrist on the outer aspect"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Minimal or no swelling"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Pain worsening with lifting objects holding hand upside down"},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Natural History (Progression of disease in the absence of treatment)"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Golfers elbow will keep causing dull pain which can worsen with activities using the forearm muscles. It may limit one from sporting activities for long term as well. However, it is a self limiting condition and resolves in majority of patients by 12 to 24 months. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"​When to seek medical help?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​Pain relieving medicines, RICE therapy are sufficient as an immediate remedy. If the pain is persistent and not settling, will need an assessment by a Sports Injury Consultant. Initial clinical assessment is necessary. MRI Scans and x-rays are usually not necessary."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"​What happens when I visit the Consultant?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​You will be asked about the nature of injury, symptoms further to that so far. Consultant will examine you and discuss the treatment modalities. In most cases, MRI scan wouldn’t be required. With simple exercise based treatment majority of these injuries heal naturally within 4 to 6 weeks. In those with poor signs of healing by 4 weeks, may need further management."}]

Title: Hamstring Strain
ContentBlocksJSON: [{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Overview"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"The word Ham-string means crooked long string like muscles on the back of the thigh. These muscles are more prone to strain as they cross 2 joints, namely the hip and the knee."},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​Hamstring injuries are one the commonest injury in athletes. The hamstring muscles aren’t used much while standing or walking, but they’re very active during activities that involve bending the knee, such as running, jumping and climbing. The hamstring tendon injury occurs when the tendons are stretched beyond their limit. They occur particularly with explosive movements such as jumping, sprinting or vaulting."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Hamstring muscle Injury"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"The typical injury results from hip flexion and knee extension. The injury can occur either at the junction between the muscle and their tendons or at the proximal attachment to the hipbone in the buttock. The injury may cause sudden pain, popping sensation, loss of strength, swelling and bruise."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Treatment"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​Rest, elevation, ice and compression with elastic (Crepe) bandage help heal majority of the Grade 1 and Grade 2 injuries. In addition, simple analgesics such as paracetamol and ibuprofen can help allay the pain. Partial tears not responding to conservative treatment can be treated effectively with PRP Injection. Grade 3 injuries with complete tears and retraction would need hamstring tear repair surgery."},{"type":"paragraph","text":"It is best to get these injuries assessed by the Specialists in the field at the earliest possible opportunity, as the results of early repair are superior to late repairs in those needing surgery for managing the injuries."}]

Title: Hip Pain
ContentBlocksJSON: [{"type":"paragraph","text":"Hip pain can present in different ways. The typical area of pain due to hip joint is the groin pain. However, people often experience pain in the C shaped area around the side below the waist all the way from front to back to the gluteus. Some experience pain in the knee due to radiation of the pain to knee from the hip."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Symptoms"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Pain: Around the hip area and the knee. Hip pain is first felt in rotational movement such as trying to sit and wear a sock or sitting cross legged. Getting up from low chairs becomes difficult. Later pain can affect the walking distance."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Stiffness: Limitation of the thigh movements inwards and outwards is often the first problem experienced. Later other movements also get affected."},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Locking and Catching: Clicking sounds in certain movements or even getting stuck in particular movements is another symptom more commonly experienced in young adults with hip problems."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Conditions"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"AVN Hip (Avasular Necrosis)"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Osteoarthritis of hip"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Hip Dysplasia"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Sequelae of Perthes disease as a child"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"SCFE (Slipped capital femoral epiphysis)"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Hip Labral tear"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"FAI (Femoro Acetabular Impingement)"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Stress fracture"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Hip Fracture"},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"When to see the Doctor?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"The persistent hip pain or pain which keeps recurring in certain hip movement with or without clicks needs the attention of the Doctor. If there is sudden pain and inability to bear weight in elderly women that needs to be assessed for the femoral (thigh bone) neck fracture. Often they may not be able to give a proper history of injury, however a low threshold to rule out any osteoporotic (bone thinning) fracture is recommended."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Prevention of hip pain"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Maintaining good Quadriceps (thigh muscle) strength"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Flexibility of hip and knee"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Foot and knee pain management so that stress on hip reduces."}]

Title: Knee Arthritis
ContentBlocksJSON: [{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"When to go Under a Knife?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"When is it right time to go for “Total Knee Replacement”?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"This has been a major dilemma for most patients and surgeons alike."},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​As this is an elective procedure (Not emergency), the same time constraints do not apply for Total Knee Replacement."},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​First of all, your symptoms should be bad enough for you to consider a Total Knee Replacement. If the pain is not under control with simple pain relief medications and if you are struggling to walk due to pain then you can consider this treatment modality."},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​Severe arthritis with bones rubbing against each other on the X-ray is NOT an indication for Total Knee Replacement, unless there are severe symptoms along with that!"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​I always advice my patients to explore alternative treatment modalities, before treading the path of Total Knee Replacement. You can try physiotherapy, as there is some evidence to support that strong quadriceps can help in taking some stress off the knee. Knee supports can be tried if helping the symptoms."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Non-surgical Treatment"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Joint injections such as steroids or hyaluronic acid can provide pain relief for 4 to 6 months and can be repeated. Although they do not cure the condition, can help in managing pain."},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Glucosamine and Glucosamine + Chondroitin Sulfate tablets orally on a daily basis can help some. A PRP Injection can help the patients with mild to moderate arthritis. Although the evidence for using these is thin, it is worth considering before going ahead with Total Knee Replacement."},{"type":"paragraph","text":"After all this, if you have made a decision to go ahead with Total Knee Replacement, then make sure that your medical problems such as diabetes, high blood pressure have been optimized prior to the surgery."}]

Title: LCL Injury
ContentBlocksJSON: [{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Overview"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​LCL or Lateral Collateral Ligament is one of the 4 main ligaments in the knee joint holding the thigh bone and leg bone together. Ligaments are rubbery ropes with connect the 2 bones. LCL along with its fellow ligament MCL on the sides of the knee joint protects and stabilizes the knee against sideward bending forces. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Why & how does it happen?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​LCL tear are one of less common injuries of the knee joint. It occurs when the knee gets pushes outwards with the impact from the inner side, when the foot is planted. Often it is twisting injury with stress on the inner side. "},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"​Who gets this injury?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​This injury occurs more often in contact sports such as football, kabaddi, rugby and also in skiing. . Fall from the two wheelers, bikes and cycles are another common reason for this injury. It is commonly seen in age group between 20 to 45 years."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"Symptoms"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Pain"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Swelling"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Feeling that knee will give away and not supporting"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Difficulty with activities of daily living due to stiffness and pain"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Within a week most patients with LCL tear will be able to walk with a slight limp"},{"type":"styled_list_item","icon":"arrow-right","text":"Persistence of instability sensation and pain in certain movements and activities ​"},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"When to seek medical help?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Initial assessment, an x-ray and pain relieving medicines is what is needed as an immediate remedy. Further assessment by an expert Arthroscopy Surgeon and MRI scan are necessary to analyze the extent of injury."},{"type":"heading","level":3,"text":"​What happens to LCL if no treatment is undertaken?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​LCL ligament resides outside the knee joint and hence may heal naturally. However, if the knee is not supported well in the first 6 weeks, the chances of natural healing dwindle. A poorly healed LCL ligament will keep causing pain and feeling of giving away whenever there is stress on the knee pushing it outwards while the leg is taking the load. "},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​What happens when I visit the Consultant?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​You will be asked about the nature of injury, symptoms further to that so far. Consultant will examine you and discuss the treatment modalities. "},{"type":"heading","level":4,"text":"​What are the treatment modalities?"},{"type":"paragraph","text":"​The treatment modalities range from simple ROM Brace immobilisation to PRP injection to LCL ligament reconstruction depending upon the severity of tear, associated injuries and the chronicity of the tear."}]

Title: MCL Injury
